title: Algebra 1
subtitle: Building the Foundation of Abstract Mathematical Thinking
description: A comprehensive Algebra 1 course using AI-driven gradual release instruction. Each lesson follows the I Do → We Do → You Do model, with adaptive AI tutoring that responds to individual student needs in real-time. Students progress through 10 units covering foundations through exponential functions, with mastery-gated advancement ensuring deep understanding before moving forward.
subject: algebra

units.title: Foundations of Algebra
units.subtitle: The Language of Mathematics
units.description: Students build fluency with variables, expressions, order of operations, and properties of real numbers. This unit establishes the algebraic vocabulary and reasoning patterns that underpin the entire course.
essentialQuestions: How do we use symbols to represent unknown quantities?
Why does the order in which we perform operations matter?
How do the properties of real numbers help us simplify expressions?
bigIdeas: Variables represent unknown or changing quantities
Mathematical expressions follow predictable rules of evaluation
Properties of real numbers are tools for simplification

lessons.title: Variables and Expressions
lessons.subtitle: Translating Words into Math
lessons.description: Students learn to identify variables, write algebraic expressions from verbal descriptions, and evaluate expressions by substituting values.

phases.title: What Are Variables and Expressions?
phases.description: Direct instruction on algebraic vocabulary and translating verbal phrases to expressions.

content.explanation: A variable is a letter that represents an unknown number. An algebraic expression combines variables, numbers, and operations. For example, if a movie ticket costs $12 and you buy 'n' tickets, the total cost is 12n. We can evaluate this expression by substituting a value for n.

workedExamples.problem: Write an expression for 'five more than a number x'
steps: Identify the operation: 'more than' means addition
workedExamples.tip: 'More than' and 'increased by' both signal addition
Always substitute with parentheses to avoid errors

workedExamples.problem: Write an expression for 'twice a number decreased by 8'
workedExamples.tip: Watch the order — 'decreased by' means subtract FROM the first quantity

keyVocabulary.definition: A letter that represents an unknown or changing value
A mathematical phrase containing numbers, variables, and operations
To find the value of an expression by substituting numbers for variables
The number multiplied by a variable (e.g., 3 in 3x)
A fixed number in an expression (e.g., 7 in 3x + 7)

aiGuidance.teachingApproach: Start with real-world contexts students relate to (money, sports stats, gaming scores). Build from concrete examples to abstract notation. Use the phrase 'math is a language' to frame variable use.
commonMisconceptions: Students may think x always equals one specific number
Confusing '5 less than x' (x - 5) with '5 less x' or writing 5 - x
Thinking 2x means '2 and x' rather than '2 times x'
scaffoldingPrompts: What operation does the word '___' tell us to use?
If I said this same thing but with specific numbers, what would it look like?
Can you point to the variable? What about the coefficient?
realWorldConnections: Sports: points per game × number of games

phases.title: Let's Practice Together
phases.description: Guided practice writing and evaluating expressions with AI scaffolding.

aiGuidance.teachingApproach: Walk through each problem WITH the student. Ask guiding questions before revealing steps. Celebrate correct reasoning even if arithmetic is off.
scaffoldingPrompts: What key word in this problem tells you what operation to use?
Try replacing the variable with the number — what do you get?
Let's break this into smaller pieces. What's the first operation?

phases.title: Independent Practice
phases.description: Students work independently on expression writing and evaluation.

aiGuidance.teachingApproach: Let the student work independently. Only intervene after 2 consecutive wrong answers. When helping, ask questions rather than showing the answer.
extensionPrompts: Can you write your own expression that uses two different operations?
What if the variable represented a negative number?

assessment.title: Variables & Expressions Mastery Check
assessment.description: Quick check to verify understanding of variables, expressions, and evaluation.

enrichment.description: Explore expressions with multiple variables and real-world modeling
challengeProblems: Write an expression for the perimeter of a rectangle with length l and width w
A phone plan charges $30/month plus $0.05 per text. Write and evaluate for 200 texts.

intervention.description: Review integer operations and basic arithmetic

lessons.title: Order of Operations
lessons.subtitle: PEMDAS and Beyond
lessons.description: Students master the conventional order for evaluating expressions, including nested grouping symbols and expressions with exponents.

phases.title: Why Order Matters
phases.description: Direct instruction on PEMDAS with emphasis on why conventions exist.

content.explanation: Without agreed-upon rules, the expression 2 + 3 × 4 could equal 20 or 14 — we need a convention so everyone gets the same answer. PEMDAS gives us that convention: Parentheses, Exponents, Multiplication/Division (left to right), Addition/Subtraction (left to right). Note: Multiplication and Division have EQUAL priority — work left to right.

workedExamples.tip: Common mistake: adding 3 + 4 first to get 14. Multiplication comes before addition!
Work from the inside out when you see nested grouping

keyVocabulary.definition: Parentheses, Exponents, Multiplication/Division, Addition/Subtraction — the order of operations
Parentheses (), brackets [], and braces {} that indicate which operations to do first

aiGuidance.teachingApproach: Emphasize that M/D and A/S are left-to-right pairs, not strict ordering. Use the 'math traffic rules' analogy — without rules, there would be chaos.
commonMisconceptions: Thinking multiplication ALWAYS comes before division
Thinking addition ALWAYS comes before subtraction
Forgetting to evaluate inside parentheses first when nested
scaffoldingPrompts: Look at the whole expression — what should you do FIRST?
Are there any grouping symbols?
Which operation has the highest priority here?
realWorldConnections: Calculator input: why pressing buttons in different orders gives different answers
Coding: programming languages follow the same rules

phases.title: Guided Practice with PEMDAS
phases.description: Work through increasingly complex expressions together.

aiGuidance.teachingApproach: Have the student identify the FIRST step before computing. Ask 'What operation comes first?' at each stage.
scaffoldingPrompts: Circle all the operations you see. Which has highest priority?
Is there anything inside grouping symbols?

lessons.title: Properties of Real Numbers
lessons.subtitle: Commutative, Associative, Distributive, and Identity
lessons.description: Students explore and apply the fundamental properties of real numbers to simplify expressions and justify algebraic steps.

phases.title: The Rules Numbers Follow
phases.description: Direct instruction on commutative, associative, distributive, identity, and inverse properties.

content.explanation: Real numbers follow predictable rules that let us rearrange and simplify expressions. The Commutative Property says order doesn't matter for addition and multiplication (a + b = b + a). The Associative Property says grouping doesn't matter ((a + b) + c = a + (b + c)). The Distributive Property connects multiplication and addition: a(b + c) = ab + ac. These aren't just rules to memorize — they're tools that make algebra work.

workedExamples.problem: Use the distributive property to simplify: 3(x + 7)
steps: Distribute 3 to each term inside parentheses
workedExamples.tip: Think of it as '3 groups of (x + 7)'

steps: This is the Associative Property of Addition
workedExamples.tip: Associative = Associates (groups) change. Commutative = Commuters (positions) change.

keyVocabulary.definition: Order doesn't matter: a + b = b + a, and a × b = b × a
Grouping doesn't matter: (a + b) + c = a + (b + c)
Multiply across addition: a(b + c) = ab + ac
Adding 0 or multiplying by 1 doesn't change the value
A number plus its opposite = 0; a number times its reciprocal = 1

aiGuidance.teachingApproach: Use memory tricks: Commutative = commute (move positions), Associative = associate (change groups). Focus on the distributive property since it's the most used in algebra.
commonMisconceptions: Thinking subtraction and division are commutative
Confusing commutative and associative properties
Only distributing to the first term inside parentheses

assessment.title: Properties of Real Numbers Mastery Check

lessons.title: Combining Like Terms
lessons.subtitle: Simplifying Expressions
lessons.description: Students learn to identify like terms and combine them to simplify algebraic expressions.

content.explanation: Like terms have the SAME variable raised to the SAME exponent. The coefficients can be different. For example, 3x and 7x are like terms (both have x¹), but 3x and 3x² are NOT like terms. To combine like terms, add or subtract their coefficients and keep the variable part the same.

steps: Identify like terms: 5x and 2x are like terms; 3 and -7 are like terms
workedExamples.tip: Rearrange terms so like terms are next to each other
Write in standard form: highest exponent first

keyVocabulary.definition: Terms with the same variable(s) raised to the same power(s)
Combine like terms to write an expression in its simplest form
Writing terms from highest to lowest degree

aiGuidance.teachingApproach: Use the 'apples and oranges' analogy — you can add 3 apples + 2 apples = 5 apples, but you can't combine 3 apples + 2 oranges into one term. Same with 3x + 2y.
commonMisconceptions: Combining terms with different exponents (3x + 2x² = 5x³ is WRONG)
Forgetting negative signs when rearranging
Thinking 3x + 2y = 5xy
scaffoldingPrompts: Can you underline all the terms with the same variable?
What's the coefficient of each like term?

lessons.title: The Distributive Property in Action
lessons.subtitle: Expanding and Simplifying
lessons.description: Deep dive into using the distributive property to expand expressions and combining with like terms for full simplification.

content.explanation: The distributive property lets us remove parentheses by multiplying each term inside by the factor outside. After distributing, we combine like terms. This two-step process — distribute then combine — is the foundation for solving equations.

workedExamples.tip: Watch the negative sign — distributing -4 means BOTH terms inside change sign

commonMisconceptions: Only distributing to the first term
Not distributing the negative sign
Sign errors with negative distribution
scaffoldingPrompts: What's outside the parentheses? Multiply it by EACH term inside.
Did you distribute to ALL terms?

unitAssessment.title: Unit 1: Foundations of Algebra Test
unitAssessment.description: Comprehensive assessment covering variables, expressions, order of operations, properties of real numbers, combining like terms, and the distributive property.

units.title: Solving Equations and Inequalities
units.subtitle: Finding the Unknown
units.description: Students develop systematic techniques for solving one-variable linear equations and inequalities, progressing from one-step to multi-step, to variables on both sides, and finally to absolute value.
essentialQuestions: What does it mean to 'solve' an equation?
How do inverse operations help us isolate variables?
How are inequalities different from equations, and how are they similar?
bigIdeas: Solving equations means finding values that make the equation true
Inverse operations undo each other to isolate the variable
Inequalities describe ranges of solutions, not single values

lessons.title: Solving One-Step Equations
lessons.subtitle: The Balance Principle
lessons.description: Students learn to solve equations using inverse operations, understanding the equation as a balanced scale.

content.explanation: An equation is like a balanced scale — both sides are equal. To solve for the variable, we need to get the variable alone on one side by using inverse operations (the opposite operation). Whatever we do to one side, we MUST do to the other side to keep the scale balanced.

steps: x has 5 added to it. The inverse of adding 5 is subtracting 5.
workedExamples.tip: Always check your answer by substituting back into the original equation

steps: x is multiplied by 3. The inverse of multiplying by 3 is dividing by 3.
x is divided by 4. The inverse of dividing by 4 is multiplying by 4.

keyVocabulary.definition: A statement that two expressions are equal, connected by an = sign
Operations that undo each other: addition/subtraction, multiplication/division
The value of the variable that makes the equation true
Get the variable by itself on one side of the equation

aiGuidance.teachingApproach: Use the balance scale metaphor consistently. Draw or describe the scale. Ask: 'What's being done TO the variable?' then 'What's the OPPOSITE of that?'
commonMisconceptions: Doing the operation to only one side
Using the same operation instead of the inverse
Sign errors when subtracting negatives
scaffoldingPrompts: What operation is being done to x?
What's the opposite of that operation?
If you do that to both sides, what do you get?
realWorldConnections: If you know the total and one part, find the missing part
Unit pricing: total ÷ quantity = price per item

lessons.title: Solving Two-Step Equations
lessons.subtitle: Undoing Two Operations
lessons.description: Students extend one-step skills to equations requiring two inverse operations, learning to undo in reverse order.

phases.title: Reverse PEMDAS: Undo in Reverse Order

content.explanation: In a two-step equation like 2x + 5 = 13, two operations have been applied to x: first multiply by 2, then add 5. To solve, we UNDO in reverse order: first subtract 5 (undo the addition), then divide by 2 (undo the multiplication). Think of it like getting dressed: socks then shoes. To undo: shoes off first, then socks. SADMEP!

steps: Undo addition first: subtract 5 from both sides → 2x = 8
Undo multiplication: divide both sides by 2 → x = 4
workedExamples.tip: SADMEP: Subtraction/Addition first, then Division/Multiplication — reverse of PEMDAS

steps: Undo subtraction: add 7 to both sides → x/3 = 9
Undo division: multiply both sides by 3 → x = 27

aiGuidance.teachingApproach: Use the 'dress/undress' analogy for reverse order. Emphasize identifying BOTH operations before starting. Color-code: circle what you're undoing at each step.
commonMisconceptions: Doing operations in the wrong order (dividing before subtracting)
Forgetting to apply the operation to BOTH sides
Arithmetic errors with negative numbers

lessons.title: Solving Multi-Step Equations
lessons.subtitle: Simplify, Then Solve
lessons.description: Students tackle equations requiring distribution, combining like terms, and multiple inverse operations.

phases.title: The Four-Step Process: Simplify → Collect → Isolate → Check

content.explanation: Multi-step equations may have parentheses, like terms on the same side, or both. Follow this process: (1) SIMPLIFY each side — distribute and combine like terms, (2) COLLECT — move variable terms to one side and constants to the other using inverse operations, (3) ISOLATE — get the variable alone, (4) CHECK — substitute your answer back into the original equation.

aiGuidance.teachingApproach: Teach the systematic 4-step approach. Have students write 'S-C-I-C' at the top of their work. Emphasize that simplification ALWAYS comes first.
commonMisconceptions: Trying to move terms before simplifying
Distribution errors with negatives
Combining terms from different sides of the equation

lessons.title: Variables on Both Sides
lessons.subtitle: Collecting Variable Terms
lessons.description: Students solve equations where the variable appears on both sides, including special cases (no solution, infinite solutions).

phases.title: When Variables Are on Both Sides

content.explanation: When variables appear on BOTH sides of the equation, add an extra step: move all variable terms to one side (usually the side where the coefficient will be positive). Then solve as normal. Watch for special cases: if variables cancel and you get a TRUE statement (like 5 = 5), the equation has infinitely many solutions. If you get a FALSE statement (like 3 = 7), there is NO solution.

workedExamples.tip: When all variables cancel and you get a false statement, the equation is a contradiction

aiGuidance.teachingApproach: Teach strategic thinking: 'Which side should I move variables to?' — choose the side that avoids negatives. Introduce special cases as discoveries, not exceptions.
commonMisconceptions: Moving variables the wrong direction
Not recognizing special cases
Sign errors when subtracting variable terms

assessment.title: Variables on Both Sides Mastery Check

lessons.title: Solving Inequalities
lessons.subtitle: Ranges of Solutions
lessons.description: Students solve linear inequalities and graph solutions on number lines, learning when to flip the inequality sign.

content.explanation: Inequalities are solved just like equations, with ONE critical difference: when you multiply or divide both sides by a NEGATIVE number, you must FLIP the inequality sign. The solution is a range of values, shown on a number line. Use an open circle for < or > (not included) and a closed circle for ≤ or ≥ (included).

steps: Graph: open circle at 3, arrow pointing right
workedExamples.tip: Open circle means 3 is NOT included in the solution

steps: Divide by -2 AND FLIP THE SIGN: x ≥ -3
Graph: closed circle at -3, arrow pointing right
workedExamples.tip: Dividing by a negative FLIPS the inequality. Think: if -2x ≤ 6, then x must be 'big enough' to make -2x small.

keyVocabulary.definition: A mathematical statement using <, >, ≤, or ≥ instead of =
All values that make the inequality true

aiGuidance.teachingApproach: Emphasize the flip rule with a concrete example: if 2 < 5, then -2 > -5. Multiplying by -1 reverses the order! Have students test solutions to verify.
commonMisconceptions: Forgetting to flip when dividing by a negative
Using wrong circle type (open vs closed)
Graphing in the wrong direction

lessons.title: Absolute Value Equations
lessons.subtitle: Distance from Zero
lessons.description: Students understand absolute value as distance and solve absolute value equations, recognizing that most produce two solutions.

content.explanation: Absolute value measures DISTANCE from zero on the number line. Since distance is always positive, |x| = 5 means x is 5 units from zero — which could be x = 5 or x = -5. To solve |expression| = k: (1) Set expression = k AND expression = -k, (2) Solve both equations. If k is negative, there's no solution (distance can't be negative).

steps: Set up two equations: x - 3 = 7 OR x - 3 = -7
Absolute value equals a negative number
workedExamples.tip: If the absolute value equals a negative number, stop — there's no solution

aiGuidance.teachingApproach: Use the number line to show distance. 'If you're 5 steps from zero, you could be at +5 or -5.' Build from simple |x| = k to |expression| = k.
commonMisconceptions: Only finding one solution
Forgetting to check for no solution when equals negative
Distributing the absolute value bars

unitAssessment.title: Unit 2: Solving Equations and Inequalities Test
unitAssessment.description: Comprehensive assessment covering one-step through multi-step equations, variables on both sides, inequalities, and absolute value equations.

units.title: Functions and Graphs
units.subtitle: Visualizing Relationships
units.description: Students develop a deep understanding of functions, learn function notation, explore domain and range, and master graphing linear functions in slope-intercept form.
essentialQuestions: What makes a relationship a function?
How do we represent functions in multiple ways?
What do slope and y-intercept tell us about a real-world situation?
bigIdeas: A function assigns exactly one output to each input
Functions can be represented as equations, tables, graphs, and verbal descriptions
Slope is rate of change; y-intercept is starting value

lessons.title: Introduction to Functions
lessons.subtitle: Input, Output, and the Vertical Line Test
lessons.description: Students understand what makes a relation a function, use function notation, and apply the vertical line test.

content.explanation: A function is a rule that assigns EXACTLY ONE output to each input. Think of it like a vending machine: you press one button (input), you get one item (output). If pressing B3 sometimes gives you chips and sometimes gives you soda, it's not functioning correctly — it's not a function! We write f(x) = 2x + 3 to mean 'the function f takes input x and gives output 2x + 3.' f(4) means 'plug in 4': f(4) = 2(4) + 3 = 11.

steps: Check: does any input repeat with a different output?
One input gives two different outputs
workedExamples.solution: Not a function — input 1 has two different outputs

workedExamples.tip: f(4) does NOT mean f times 4. It means 'f OF 4' — plug 4 into the rule.

keyVocabulary.definition: A rule that assigns exactly one output to each input
The set of all possible inputs (x-values)
The set of all possible outputs (y-values)
f(x) means 'the output of function f when the input is x'
If any vertical line crosses a graph more than once, it's NOT a function

aiGuidance.teachingApproach: Use the vending machine analogy. Then introduce function notation carefully — students often think f(x) means multiplication. Use mapping diagrams before jumping to equations.
commonMisconceptions: Thinking f(x) means f × x
Confusing domain and range
Thinking functions must be linear

lessons.title: Domain and Range
lessons.subtitle: What Goes In, What Comes Out
lessons.description: Students identify domain and range from graphs, tables, sets of ordered pairs, and real-world contexts.

content.explanation: Domain = all possible inputs (x-values). Range = all possible outputs (y-values). From a graph, domain is how far left and right the graph extends; range is how far up and down. For real-world situations, think about what values make sense — you can't have negative time or a negative number of people.

workedExamples.problem: Find the domain and range of {(1,4), (2,7), (3,10), (4,13)}

aiGuidance.teachingApproach: Use the 'input/output' framing consistently. For graphs, teach the 'shadow' method: imagine shining a light from above onto the x-axis (domain) and from the side onto the y-axis (range).
commonMisconceptions: Confusing domain and range
Not using inequality notation for continuous graphs
Forgetting to consider real-world constraints

lessons.title: Understanding Slope
lessons.subtitle: Rate of Change
lessons.description: Students understand slope as rate of change, calculate slope from two points, and interpret slope in context.

content.explanation: Slope measures how steep a line is — it's the rate of change. Slope = rise/run = (change in y)/(change in x) = (y₂ - y₁)/(x₂ - x₁). Positive slope goes uphill (left to right), negative slope goes downhill, zero slope is horizontal, undefined slope is vertical.

steps: Use the formula: m = (y₂ - y₁)/(x₂ - x₁)
workedExamples.tip: A slope of 2 means: for every 1 unit right, go 2 units up

workedExamples.problem: A car travels 150 miles in 3 hours. What's the rate of change?
steps: Rate of change = change in distance / change in time
workedExamples.solution: 50 mph — slope IS rate of change!

aiGuidance.teachingApproach: Connect slope to real rates students understand: speed, cost per item, growth rate. Use the staircase visual — how many steps up for each step over.
commonMisconceptions: Subtracting coordinates in wrong order (but only one, not both)
Rise/run vs run/rise confusion
Thinking vertical lines have slope of 0

lessons.title: Graphing Linear Equations
lessons.subtitle: y = mx + b in Action
lessons.description: Students graph linear equations in slope-intercept form by plotting the y-intercept and using slope.

content.explanation: Every linear equation y = mx + b gives you two pieces of graphing information: b is where the line crosses the y-axis (y-intercept), and m tells you the slope (rise/run). To graph: (1) Plot the y-intercept (0, b), (2) From there, use slope as rise/run to find the next point, (3) Draw a straight line through the points.

steps: Use slope 2 = 2/1: from (0,-3), go up 2, right 1 → (1, -1)
Plot another point: from (1,-1), go up 2, right 1 → (2, 1)
Draw the line through all points
workedExamples.tip: Write slope as a fraction (rise/run) even if it's a whole number: 2 = 2/1

aiGuidance.teachingApproach: Teach the 'start-and-step' method: start at b, step by m. Use graph paper visuals. Show that every point on the line satisfies the equation.
commonMisconceptions: Plotting y-intercept on x-axis
Going run/rise instead of rise/run
Connecting with a curve instead of a straight line

lessons.title: Writing Linear Equations
lessons.subtitle: From Information to Equation
lessons.description: Students write equations in slope-intercept form from graphs, tables, two points, and word problems.

phases.title: Writing y = mx + b from Different Sources

content.explanation: To write y = mx + b, you need two things: slope (m) and y-intercept (b). From a graph: read slope and y-intercept directly. From two points: calculate slope, then substitute one point to find b. From a word problem: rate of change is m, starting value is b.

workedExamples.problem: Write the equation of a line passing through (1, 5) and (3, 11)
steps: Use y = mx + b with one point: 5 = 3(1) + b

workedExamples.problem: A gym charges $25/month plus a $50 signup fee. Write the equation for total cost after m months.
workedExamples.tip: In word problems: 'per' signals slope, 'initial/starting/fixed' signals y-intercept

aiGuidance.teachingApproach: Practice all four representations: equation ↔ graph ↔ table ↔ verbal description. Students should be fluent moving between all four.
commonMisconceptions: Swapping m and b
Not finding b after calculating slope
Confusing which value is slope vs y-intercept in word problems

unitAssessment.title: Unit 3: Functions and Graphs Test
unitAssessment.description: Comprehensive assessment on functions, domain/range, slope, graphing, and writing linear equations.

performanceTask.scenario: A local food truck sells tacos for $3 each plus a $2 plate fee. A competing food truck charges $4 per taco with no plate fee. Model both pricing structures with equations, graph them, and determine when each truck is a better deal.
requirements: Graph both lines on the same coordinate plane
Explain which truck is better for different quantities

rubric.description: Both equations correctly written in slope-intercept form
Both lines graphed with correct slope and intercept
Correct intersection point identified and verified
Clear explanation of when each option is better

units.title: Systems of Equations and Inequalities
units.subtitle: When Two Relationships Meet
units.description: Students learn to solve systems of linear equations using graphing, substitution, and elimination methods. They interpret solutions as intersection points and apply systems to real-world comparison problems.
essentialQuestions: What does the solution to a system of equations represent?
When should you use graphing vs substitution vs elimination?
How do systems help us compare real-world options?
bigIdeas: The solution to a system is the point that satisfies ALL equations simultaneously
Different methods are more efficient for different types of systems
Systems model comparison and optimization problems in the real world

lessons.title: Solving Systems by Graphing
lessons.subtitle: Where Two Lines Meet
lessons.description: Students solve systems of linear equations by graphing both lines and identifying the intersection point.

phases.title: Systems of Equations: The Big Idea

content.explanation: A system of equations is two or more equations with the same variables. The SOLUTION is the point (x, y) that makes BOTH equations true at the same time. Graphically, this is where the two lines intersect. There are three possibilities: one solution (lines cross), no solution (parallel lines — same slope, different y-intercept), or infinitely many solutions (same line — identical equations).

workedExamples.problem: Solve the system by graphing: y = 2x + 1 and y = -x + 7
steps: Graph y = 2x + 1: start at (0,1), slope 2/1 → points (0,1), (1,3), (2,5)
Graph y = -x + 7: start at (0,7), slope -1/1 → points (0,7), (1,6), (2,5)
Both lines pass through (2, 5) — that's the intersection!
workedExamples.tip: Always check your solution in BOTH equations

steps: Both lines have slope 3 but different y-intercepts
workedExamples.tip: Same slope + different y-intercept = parallel = no solution

keyVocabulary.definition: Two or more equations with the same variables, solved simultaneously
The ordered pair(s) that make ALL equations true
A system with at least one solution
A system with no solution (parallel lines)
A system with infinitely many solutions (same line)

aiGuidance.teachingApproach: Frame systems as 'comparison problems.' When do two plans cost the same? When do two athletes have the same stats? The intersection IS the answer.
commonMisconceptions: Reading the wrong intersection point from the graph
Thinking no intersection means the answer is (0, 0)
Only checking the solution in one equation
scaffoldingPrompts: Can you graph each line separately first?
What are the slopes? Are the lines parallel?
Where do the lines cross? Read those coordinates carefully.
realWorldConnections: Comparing phone plans: when does Plan A become cheaper than Plan B?
Two runners at different speeds — when does the faster one catch up?

aiGuidance.teachingApproach: Walk through each graph step by step. Have the student graph one line, then the other, then identify the intersection.

lessons.title: Solving Systems by Substitution
lessons.subtitle: Replace and Solve
lessons.description: Students solve systems algebraically by isolating one variable and substituting into the other equation.

content.explanation: Substitution works by solving one equation for one variable, then plugging that expression into the other equation. This reduces a two-variable problem to a one-variable equation you already know how to solve. Steps: (1) Solve one equation for one variable, (2) Substitute that expression into the other equation, (3) Solve for the remaining variable, (4) Back-substitute to find the first variable, (5) Check in both original equations.

steps: First equation already solved for y: y = 3x - 2
workedExamples.tip: Look for an equation already solved for a variable — that's the easiest one to substitute

steps: Solve first equation for x: x = 7 - 2y
workedExamples.tip: Use parentheses when substituting to avoid sign errors

aiGuidance.teachingApproach: Emphasize choosing the 'easier' equation to solve first — one with a coefficient of 1 is ideal. Show that substitution gives the exact answer (unlike graphing which can be imprecise).
commonMisconceptions: Substituting into the SAME equation instead of the OTHER equation
Forgetting parentheses when substituting
Not back-substituting to find the second variable
Sign errors during distribution
scaffoldingPrompts: Which equation is easiest to solve for a variable?
Now plug that expression into the OTHER equation.
You found x — now go back and find y.

lessons.title: Solving Systems by Elimination
lessons.subtitle: Add or Subtract to Eliminate
lessons.description: Students solve systems by adding or subtracting equations to eliminate one variable.

content.explanation: Elimination works by adding or subtracting the equations so one variable cancels out. If the coefficients of one variable are opposites (like 3y and -3y), just add. If not, multiply one or both equations to CREATE opposite coefficients, then add. Steps: (1) Align equations vertically, (2) Make coefficients of one variable opposites, (3) Add equations to eliminate that variable, (4) Solve for remaining variable, (5) Substitute back.

workedExamples.tip: Look for opposite coefficients first — those are the easiest to eliminate

steps: No opposite coefficients yet. Multiply second equation by -2: -2x - 2y = -12
workedExamples.tip: When multiplying, multiply EVERY term in the equation

aiGuidance.teachingApproach: Show elimination as a strategic choice. Compare efficiency: substitution is better when one variable has coefficient 1; elimination is better when coefficients are already close to opposites.
commonMisconceptions: Not multiplying every term when scaling an equation
Sign errors when adding equations
Forgetting to solve for the second variable
scaffoldingPrompts: Which variable would be easiest to eliminate?
What would you need to multiply by to get opposite coefficients?
Did you multiply ALL terms in the equation?

lessons.title: Systems Word Problems
lessons.subtitle: Real-World Applications
lessons.description: Students translate real-world scenarios into systems of equations and solve using the most efficient method.

phases.title: Setting Up Systems from Word Problems

content.explanation: Many real-world problems involve two unknowns and two relationships — perfect for systems! The key is translating: (1) Define your variables clearly, (2) Write TWO equations from the given information, (3) Choose the best method to solve, (4) Answer the original question (not just 'x = ...').

workedExamples.problem: Movie tickets cost $8 for adults and $5 for children. A group of 12 people paid $81 total. How many adults and children?
steps: Define variables: a = adults, c = children
Solve by substitution: a = 12 - c → 8(12 - c) + 5c = 81

workedExamples.problem: A boat travels 30 miles upstream in 3 hours and 30 miles downstream in 2 hours. Find the boat's speed and the current's speed.
steps: Variables: b = boat speed, c = current speed
Upstream: boat works against current → (b - c) × 3 = 30 → b - c = 10
Downstream: boat works with current → (b + c) × 2 = 30 → b + c = 15

aiGuidance.teachingApproach: Focus on the SETUP, not just the solving. The hardest part is translating English to math. Use a structured approach: (1) What are the unknowns? (2) What are the relationships?
commonMisconceptions: Writing only one equation instead of two
Mixing up which equation represents which constraint
Giving the mathematical answer without answering the actual question

scaffoldingPrompts: What are the TWO unknowns in this problem?
Can you write the first relationship as an equation?
Now what's the SECOND relationship?

lessons.title: Systems of Inequalities
lessons.subtitle: Shading Solution Regions
lessons.description: Students graph systems of linear inequalities and identify the solution region as the overlap of shaded areas.

content.explanation: A system of inequalities has a solution REGION, not a single point. To find it: (1) Graph each inequality as a line (dashed for < or >, solid for ≤ or ≥), (2) Shade the correct side of each line, (3) The solution is the OVERLAP — where all shading meets. Any point in the overlap region satisfies ALL inequalities.

workedExamples.problem: Graph the system: y > 2x - 1 and y ≤ -x + 4
steps: Graph y = 2x - 1 as a DASHED line (strict >), shade ABOVE
Graph y = -x + 4 as a SOLID line (≤), shade BELOW
The solution region is where both shadings overlap
workedExamples.tip: Use a test point (often (0,0) if it's not on either line) to check which side to shade

aiGuidance.teachingApproach: Build from single inequality graphing (Unit 2). Use color coding — shade each inequality in a different color so the overlap is clear.
commonMisconceptions: Using a solid line when it should be dashed
Shading the wrong side
Thinking the solution is the intersection point instead of the region

unitAssessment.title: Unit 4: Systems of Equations and Inequalities Test
unitAssessment.description: Comprehensive assessment on solving systems by graphing, substitution, and elimination, word problems, and systems of inequalities.

performanceTask.scenario: You and a friend are planning a road trip. You need to rent a car. Company A charges $40/day plus $0.15/mile. Company B charges $60/day plus $0.05/mile. Set up a system, solve it, and recommend which company to choose based on your expected daily mileage.
requirements: Define variables and write a system of equations
Solve using at least two different methods
Graph both equations and identify the break-even point
Write a recommendation with mathematical justification

rubric.description: Variables defined and equations correctly written
Solved correctly using at least two methods
Both lines graphed accurately with break-even identified
Clear, well-justified recommendation based on math

units.title: Polynomials
units.subtitle: Building with Algebraic Blocks
units.description: Students learn to classify, add, subtract, multiply, and factor polynomials. This unit bridges linear algebra to quadratics, building the manipulation skills needed for advanced equation solving.
essentialQuestions: How are polynomial operations extensions of arithmetic?
What does factoring 'undo' and why is it useful?
How do exponent rules make polynomial multiplication efficient?
bigIdeas: Polynomials are built from simpler terms combined with addition and subtraction
Factoring is the reverse of multiplication — it breaks expressions into products
Exponent rules govern how variable terms combine

lessons.title: Exponent Rules
lessons.subtitle: Product, Quotient, and Power Rules
lessons.description: Students master the laws of exponents for multiplication, division, and powers of powers.

content.explanation: Exponents follow three key rules. Product Rule: x^a · x^b = x^(a+b) — when multiplying same bases, ADD exponents. Quotient Rule: x^a / x^b = x^(a-b) — when dividing same bases, SUBTRACT exponents. Power Rule: (x^a)^b = x^(ab) — when raising a power to a power, MULTIPLY exponents. These rules only work when the BASES are the same!

workedExamples.tip: Think expanded: (x·x·x)(x·x·x·x·x) = 8 x's multiplied = x⁸

steps: Apply power to BOTH coefficient and variable
workedExamples.tip: Don't forget to raise the coefficient to the power too!

keyVocabulary.definition: The number or variable being raised to a power
The power indicating how many times the base is multiplied by itself
x^a · x^b = x^(a+b) — add exponents when multiplying same bases
x^a / x^b = x^(a-b) — subtract exponents when dividing same bases
(x^a)^b = x^(ab) — multiply exponents for a power of a power

aiGuidance.teachingApproach: Use expanded form to PROVE each rule. Show x³ · x² = (x·x·x)(x·x) = x⁵ before introducing the shortcut. Create a reference card students can use.
commonMisconceptions: Multiplying exponents instead of adding (product rule)
Applying rules when bases are different (x³ · y² ≠ xy⁵)
Forgetting to apply power to coefficients
Confusing product rule with power rule
scaffoldingPrompts: Are the bases the same? Which rule applies?
Try writing it in expanded form — how many x's total?
Did you apply the exponent to the coefficient too?

lessons.title: Adding and Subtracting Polynomials
lessons.subtitle: Combining Like Terms with Polynomials
lessons.description: Students add and subtract polynomials by identifying and combining like terms, writing results in standard form.

content.explanation: Adding polynomials is straightforward: combine like terms. Subtracting is trickier: you must distribute the negative sign to EVERY term in the polynomial being subtracted, then combine like terms. Write your final answer in standard form (highest degree to lowest).

workedExamples.tip: The most common error is forgetting to change ALL signs when subtracting. -(2x² - 4x + 6) = -2x² + 4x - 6

aiGuidance.teachingApproach: Use the vertical alignment method for visual learners. Show horizontal and vertical methods side by side. Emphasize the subtraction trap.
commonMisconceptions: Only distributing negative to the first term
Combining terms with different exponents
Forgetting to write in standard form

lessons.title: Multiplying Polynomials
lessons.subtitle: From Monomials to FOIL
lessons.description: Students multiply monomials by polynomials (distribution) and binomials by binomials (FOIL method).

content.explanation: Monomial × Polynomial: distribute the monomial to every term. Binomial × Binomial: use FOIL (First, Outer, Inner, Last) — it's just double distribution. Every term in the first binomial must multiply every term in the second. Then combine like terms.

workedExamples.tip: Notice the pattern: (x + a)(x + b) = x² + (a+b)x + ab. The middle term is the SUM, the last term is the PRODUCT.

keyVocabulary.definition: First, Outer, Inner, Last — a method for multiplying two binomials
A polynomial with one term (e.g., 3x²)
A polynomial with two terms (e.g., x + 3)
A polynomial with three terms (e.g., x² + 5x + 6)

aiGuidance.teachingApproach: Use the area model (box method) as a visual alternative to FOIL. It generalizes to any polynomial multiplication and makes the connection to factoring clearer.
commonMisconceptions: Only multiplying first terms: (x+3)(x+5) = x² + 15 (missing middle terms)
Sign errors with negative terms in FOIL
Forgetting to combine like terms after multiplying
scaffoldingPrompts: Did you multiply EVERY term in the first by EVERY term in the second?
Can you draw the box method? It shows all four multiplications.
After FOILing, are there like terms to combine?

lessons.title: Factoring GCF and Trinomials
lessons.subtitle: Unraveling Products
lessons.description: Students factor out the greatest common factor and factor trinomials of the form x² + bx + c by finding two numbers that multiply to c and add to b.

content.explanation: Factoring 'undoes' multiplication. Step 1: Always check for a GCF first. Pull out the largest factor common to ALL terms. Step 2: For trinomials x² + bx + c, find two numbers that MULTIPLY to c and ADD to b. Those numbers go in the binomials: (x + ?)(x + ?). Verify by FOILing back!

steps: Find GCF: GCF of 6x² and 9x is 3x
workedExamples.tip: Always factor out the GCF as your FIRST step, even before trying other methods

steps: Find two numbers that multiply to 12 and add to 7
Find two numbers that multiply to -14 and add to -5
workedExamples.tip: When c is negative, one factor is positive and one is negative

aiGuidance.teachingApproach: Frame factoring as 'reverse FOIL.' Use the diamond/X method: product goes on top, sum on bottom, find the two side numbers. Always emphasize checking by multiplying back.
commonMisconceptions: Not pulling out the full GCF
Confusing 'multiply to c' with 'add to c'
Sign errors when c is negative
Forgetting to check by multiplying back
scaffoldingPrompts: Is there a common factor in ALL terms?
What two numbers multiply to ___ and add to ___?
Let's check: FOIL your answer and see if you get the original.

lessons.title: Special Factoring Patterns
lessons.subtitle: Difference of Squares and Perfect Square Trinomials
lessons.description: Students recognize and factor special polynomial patterns: difference of squares and perfect square trinomials.

content.explanation: Two special patterns save time. Difference of Squares: a² - b² = (a + b)(a - b). Only works for SUBTRACTION of two perfect squares. Perfect Square Trinomials: a² + 2ab + b² = (a + b)² and a² - 2ab + b² = (a - b)². The middle term is always twice the product of a and b.

steps: Recognize: x² is a perfect square, 25 = 5², and we have subtraction
Apply difference of squares: a² - b² = (a+b)(a-b)

workedExamples.tip: Check: is the middle term = 2 × √(first) × √(last)? If yes, it's a perfect square trinomial.

aiGuidance.teachingApproach: Teach pattern recognition. Have students check: (1) Is it a difference? (2) Are both terms perfect squares? Then it's DOS. For PST: Is the middle term = 2ab?
commonMisconceptions: Trying to factor a SUM of squares (x² + 25 does NOT factor over real numbers)
Not recognizing coefficients as perfect squares (4x² = (2x)²)
Confusing difference of squares with perfect square trinomials

unitAssessment.title: Unit 5: Polynomials Test
unitAssessment.description: Comprehensive assessment covering exponent rules, polynomial operations, and all factoring methods.

units.title: Quadratic Functions
units.subtitle: Parabolas, Vertices, and the Quadratic Formula
units.description: Students explore quadratic equations and their parabolic graphs. They learn to solve quadratics by factoring, square roots, completing the square, and the quadratic formula, and apply these skills to real-world problems involving projectile motion and optimization.
essentialQuestions: How is a quadratic function different from a linear function?
Why do quadratic equations sometimes have two solutions, one, or none?
When should you use each method to solve a quadratic?
bigIdeas: Quadratic functions model situations with acceleration, area, and optimization
The graph of a quadratic is a parabola with a vertex that represents a maximum or minimum
Different solving methods are tools — choose the most efficient one for each situation

lessons.title: Graphing Quadratic Functions
lessons.subtitle: The Shape of a Parabola
lessons.description: Students graph quadratic functions, identify the vertex, axis of symmetry, and direction of opening.

content.explanation: A quadratic function has the form y = ax² + bx + c. Its graph is a U-shaped curve called a parabola. Key features: The VERTEX is the highest or lowest point. The AXIS OF SYMMETRY is a vertical line through the vertex: x = -b/(2a). If a > 0, the parabola opens UP (vertex is minimum). If a < 0, it opens DOWN (vertex is maximum). The larger |a| is, the narrower the parabola.

workedExamples.problem: Graph y = x² - 4x + 3. Find vertex, axis of symmetry, and y-intercept.
steps: Additional point: x=1 → y = 1-4+3 = 0, so (1,0) reflects to (3,0)
Plot points and draw smooth U-shaped curve
workedExamples.solution: Vertex (2,-1), axis of symmetry x=2, y-intercept (0,3)
workedExamples.tip: The parabola is symmetric — once you find points on one side of the vertex, reflect them to the other side

keyVocabulary.definition: A function of the form f(x) = ax² + bx + c where a ≠ 0
The U-shaped graph of a quadratic function
The maximum or minimum point of a parabola
The vertical line x = -b/(2a) that divides the parabola into two mirror images
Points where the parabola crosses the x-axis (also called zeros or roots)

aiGuidance.teachingApproach: Compare to linear functions: linear = constant rate of change (straight), quadratic = changing rate of change (curved). Use projectile motion as a hook — throwing a ball traces a parabola.
commonMisconceptions: Connecting plotted points with straight lines instead of a curve
Forgetting the negative sign in -b/(2a)
Confusing which way the parabola opens based on the sign of a
realWorldConnections: Area optimization (maximum garden area with fixed fencing)

lessons.title: Solving Quadratics by Factoring
lessons.subtitle: Zero Product Property
lessons.description: Students solve quadratic equations by factoring and applying the zero product property.

content.explanation: The Zero Product Property states: if ab = 0, then a = 0 OR b = 0 (or both). This is the key to solving by factoring. Steps: (1) Get equation in standard form: ax² + bx + c = 0, (2) Factor the left side completely, (3) Set each factor equal to zero, (4) Solve each resulting equation. Most quadratics have TWO solutions because the parabola crosses the x-axis at two points.

steps: Set each factor = 0: x + 2 = 0 or x + 3 = 0

workedExamples.tip: Always get the equation equal to 0 FIRST. You can't use ZPP if it equals something other than 0.

aiGuidance.teachingApproach: Connect to graphing: the solutions are where the parabola crosses the x-axis (x-intercepts/zeros). Graph the function to verify the solutions visually.
commonMisconceptions: Not setting the equation equal to 0 first
Only finding one solution instead of two
Applying ZPP to an equation that equals something other than 0

lessons.title: Solving by Taking Square Roots
lessons.subtitle: When There's No Linear Term
lessons.description: Students solve quadratics in the form ax² + c = 0 or (x - h)² = k by taking square roots.

content.explanation: When a quadratic has NO linear term (no bx), or is in the form (x - h)² = k, you can solve by isolating the squared term and taking the square root of both sides. Remember: √(x²) = ±x, so you always get TWO answers (positive and negative). Exception: if you end up taking the square root of a negative number, there are no real solutions.

steps: Take square root of both sides: x = ±√49

workedExamples.tip: This form shows vertex form: the solutions are equidistant from the vertex x = 3

aiGuidance.teachingApproach: Emphasize the ± symbol — students consistently forget the negative solution. Connect to the graph: a parabola (usually) crosses the x-axis at TWO symmetric points.
commonMisconceptions: Forgetting the ± (only writing the positive root)
Taking the square root of a negative and thinking the answer is negative
Not isolating the squared term before taking the root

lessons.title: The Quadratic Formula
lessons.subtitle: The Universal Solver
lessons.description: Students learn and apply the quadratic formula to solve any quadratic equation, including the discriminant for determining the number of solutions.

content.explanation: The quadratic formula works for ANY quadratic ax² + bx + c = 0: x = (-b ± √(b² - 4ac)) / (2a). The discriminant (b² - 4ac) tells you HOW MANY solutions exist: Positive discriminant → 2 real solutions. Zero discriminant → 1 real solution (vertex touches x-axis). Negative discriminant → 0 real solutions (parabola doesn't cross x-axis).

workedExamples.problem: How many solutions does x² + 4x + 5 = 0 have?
steps: The parabola doesn't cross the x-axis
workedExamples.tip: You can check with the discriminant BEFORE doing the full formula to save time

keyVocabulary.definition: x = (-b ± √(b²-4ac)) / (2a) — solves any quadratic equation
b² - 4ac — determines the number and type of solutions

aiGuidance.teachingApproach: Teach careful substitution — the most common errors are sign errors with negative b and computing b² - 4ac. Have students identify a, b, c FIRST, then substitute step by step.
commonMisconceptions: Putting -b as a negative when b is already negative (double negative)
Dividing only part of the numerator by 2a
Forgetting the ± (only computing one solution)
Arithmetic errors inside the radical
scaffoldingPrompts: What are a, b, and c? Write them down before substituting.
What is the discriminant? What does it tell you?
Be careful with -b. What is b? What is -b?

lessons.title: Quadratic Word Problems
lessons.subtitle: Parabolas in the Real World
lessons.description: Students apply quadratic equations to real-world scenarios including projectile motion, area optimization, and revenue modeling.

content.explanation: Quadratics model many real situations. Projectile motion: h(t) = -16t² + v₀t + h₀ (height as a function of time). Area optimization: maximize area with a fixed perimeter. Revenue: R = price × quantity, where quantity often decreases as price increases. The vertex gives you the maximum/minimum value, and the x-intercepts tell you when something hits zero.

workedExamples.problem: A ball is thrown upward from 6 feet with initial velocity 40 ft/s. When does it hit the ground? h(t) = -16t² + 40t + 6
steps: Use quadratic formula: a=-16, b=40, c=6
workedExamples.tip: In projectile problems, reject negative time values — they don't make physical sense

workedExamples.problem: A farmer has 80 feet of fencing. What dimensions maximize the area of a rectangular pen built against a barn (3 sides of fencing)?
steps: Let x = width. Then length = 80 - 2x (fencing for two widths and one length)
This is a downward parabola — vertex is the maximum

aiGuidance.teachingApproach: Focus on translating the real-world situation into a quadratic model FIRST. Then identify what the question asks: maximum/minimum (find vertex) or when something equals zero (find x-intercepts).
commonMisconceptions: Using the wrong formula for the real-world context
Accepting negative time or negative length answers
Finding the vertex when the question asks for roots (or vice versa)
realWorldConnections: Sports: trajectory of a ball, optimal launch angle
Engineering: bridge arch design, antenna parabolic shapes

unitAssessment.title: Unit 6: Quadratic Functions Test
unitAssessment.description: Comprehensive assessment covering graphing parabolas, solving quadratics by all methods, discriminant analysis, and real-world applications.

performanceTask.scenario: A school is designing a new basketball court with a half-court shooting contest. The ball leaves a player's hand at 8 feet high with an initial velocity of 20 ft/s at a 45-degree angle. The hoop is 10 feet high and 25 feet away. Model the trajectory with a quadratic, determine if the shot is successful, and find the maximum height the ball reaches.
requirements: Write a quadratic model for the ball's trajectory
Find the maximum height and when it occurs
Determine if the ball reaches hoop height at the correct distance

rubric.description: Accurate parabolic graph with labeled key features
Correct determination of whether the shot is successful with justification
